COL.DATA: Date or place of composition is not known. But it must be before 626H, as there is a samāʿ on Shehit Ali 2826 dated 22nd of Dhū al-Ḥijja 626H.

A treatise on the servants of God according to the different character traits (akhlāq) of the perfect human being (al-insān al-kāmil). Each servant (ʿabd Allāh) represents a spiritual modality symbolised by the association of a Divine Name and the name of a particular prophet or saint. The work is in two parts; the first consisting of 50 ʿabādila divided into five sections, the second of 67. Pablo Beneito supports Michel Chodkiewicz in relating the first 114 to the 114 suras of the Qurʾān.

OY lists 16 mss., at least seven of which can be considered historic. The best is Yusuf Aga 4859, a partial holograph with a samāʿ dated 641H. Different copies have different numbers of chapters: Ayasofia 4817 and Yusuf Aga 4859 have 117, Shehit Ali 2826 114, the Cairo printed edition (1969) 96. According to Pablo Beneito, who has made a detailed study of the text, 117 is the correct number.

كتاب الأجوبة العربية في شرح النصائح الوسفية
al-ḥamdu lillāh alladhī hadānā li-hadhā wa-mā kunā li-nahtadī lawlā an hadānā Allāh laqad jaʿat rusul rabbina bi-l-ḥaqq

Wise sayings, accompanied by explanatory notes. IA says in the introduction that it is a collection of sayings by a certain mystic called ʿAlī al-Kurdī who was ‘smitten with divine love’, and he has appended a commentary on these sayings. Claude Addas adds: “Al-Ajwiba al-‘Arabiyya fî sharh al-nasâ’ih al-Yûsufiyya est une commentaire par Ibn ‘Arabî d’une risâla concernant les devoirs du murîd à l’égard de son shaykh rédigée par Yûsuf b. Ibrâhîm al-Shâfi’î sous l’inspiration de la rûhâniya de ‘Alî al-Kurdî, un “fou” (muwallah ) notoire de Damas (I.A. l’a rencontré, cf.,Fut., II, 522, ed. Bûlaq).”

OY lists five mss. of which two, Husein Celebi 447 and Yusuf Aga 4860, although undated, are very early, whilst Yusuf Aga 4860 is from SQ’s library, and is possibly 7th or 8th century. The internal evidence of the text – for example, the language and the mention of his wife – is strong evidence that it is by IA. In addition, the title is listed in one of the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142), and it does not seem to be attributed to anyone else. Claude Addas confirms this stating that:: “L’attribution de ce texte à Ibn ‘Arabî ne fait aucun doute ; on y trouve de nombreuses références autobiographiques, par ex, l’investiture de la khirqa par ‘Abd Allâh b. Jâmī”.A number of the poems in this work appear clustered in the Paris Diwan (B.N. 2348) and seemingly nowhere else. Further information on the fully digitized text of RG 9 found in Word format at cb.rayaheen.net/userfiles/download.php?id=1395‎, which extracts as a Word document with name شرح روحانية الشيخ الكردي.doc. The text itself carries a title not listed by Osman Yahia under RG 9, namely: شرح ما نطقت به روحانية سيدي علي الكردي . JC has compared that text to Yusuf Aga 4860 and Husein Celebi 447. The 202 page text in the Word document closely matches the complete text found in Husein Celebi 447 ff.1a-149b. Decapitated Yusuf Aga 4860 p.207 – which we estimate is missing the first 14 pages (7 folios) – starts with the text found at the end of page 11 of the Word document (cf. Husein Celebi f.9a line 2). PDF versions are also available via Google (شرح روحانية الشيخ الكردي لسيدي ابن عربي.pdf).

‘I composed it in Jerusalem (Bayt al-Muqaddas) in an hour of the daytime.’” (Vel.51/19a)
Treatise on the unity symbolically represented by the letter Alif. Alternative title is K. al-Aḥadiyya.

Over 30 mss. are listed by OY, of which six can be considered to be historic. The best is Shehit Ali 2813, which was copied by Ayyūb b. Badr and read in front of IA in Damascus in 621H. According to OY, the work was written in 601H in Jerusalem on the basis of a note on Veliyuddin 51, but our investigation shows that no date is given. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley, Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyuddin 51, JMIAS, 40 (2006), pp. 101-116.)
K. al-Alif wa huwa kitāb al-aḥadiyya

Dating: The title K. al-Alif wa huwa k. al-ahadiyya is written on 19a, and underneath there is a note, which we believe is in the same hand, that translates as: Composed by Muhyî al-dîn ibn al-‘Arabî, who said (may God have mercy on him) “I composed it in Jerusalem (bayt al-muqaddas) in an hour in the daytime.” On 26a, at the end, a further note repeats this information and adds that the original was in Ibn ‘Arabî’s handwriting. Osman Yahia again concludes, on the basis of this second note, that the text was written in Jerusalem in 601,[10] but we could not find a date. The year 601 would be a reasonable conjecture, however, given the other notes in the collection. Title: Can be seen as two alternate titles or one full title... The title translates as “The Firm Rule regarding the conditions necessary for people on God’s Path”. The aim of the work is to give advice to spiritual guides on the kind of language and teaching which should be offered to different types of students.

A much copied work, verified by at least six historic mss, three of them definitely copied from originals. The best are Shehit Ali 1341, written around 724H in Damascus, copied from an original by IA and certified by him, and Ayasofya 4875 (probably dated 705H). OY believed the work was written in Konya in 602H on basis of a note in Veliyuddin 51 (110b), but further inspection of the note shows that the place of writing is Damascus. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley, Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyuddin 51, JMIAS, 40 (2006), pp. 101-116.)
K. al-Amr al-muḥkam al-marbūt fī mā yalzam ahl ṭarīq Allāh min al-shurūṭ.

Clark and McAuley, 2006: At the end, on 110b, there is a note saying that the book was completed in Damascus in Jumâdâ al-ûlâ 602 by the hand of its author […] Osman Yahia asserts that the text was completed in Konya in 602, based (he says) on evidence within the text.[21] We can only assume that this refers to three lines from the bottom on 95b: wa-laqad haddathanî Awhad al-dîn Hâmid ibn Abî l-Fakhr al-Kirmânî bi-manzilî fî madînat Qûniya fî shahr Safar sanat 602 (“Awhad al-dîn Kirmânî related to me in my home in the city of Konya in Safar 602 …”). Written after a vision in 595H, this work is devoted to bringing out the role of the mahdī – the “rightly guided leader” – and the Seal of the Saints (whom he identifies with Jesus), discussing both a prophetic aspect which looks to the unfolding of their functions in time, and a mystical aspect which understands them as realities which can be realised in the heart of the complete human being.

Verified by at least four historic mss. The best is Berlin Oct. 3266 (described by Gerald Elmore in Islamic Sainthood in the Fullness of Time (Leiden, 1999) pp. 197-199), which was written in 597H, and is the oldest known ms. of IA’s. Also excellent is Private 1, written in 637H by a well-known disciple, Muḥammad b. ʿAbd al-Qādir al-Anṣāri, in Damascus and checked against the original in IA’s hand; however, according to Abrar Ahmed Shahi, who has prepared a critical edition of the text, this mss contains only about 50% of the work. Another early copy, dated 707H in the Turkish catalogue (http://ktp.isam.org.tr/), is Veliyuddin 1743 ff.1-79. Another copy, dated 834H, in Milli Hk 15 ff.12b-43b, is available in digital reproduction here: https://www.yazmalar.gov.tr/detay_goster.php?k=77129 JC notes that most of the poems from ʿAnqāʾ mughrib are also found as a block – and as complete poems – in the Dīwān, p. 26-33.

Written in answer to a request from a friend and companion that he should explain the journey of ascension to the ‘lord of power’ and the return to the creatures. It describes the spiritual quest in terms of a non-stop ascension through the various levels of existence and knowledge leading to the level of human perfection.

A very commonly copied work in the early collections, verified by at least four historic mss. The best is probably Yusuf Aga 7838, which is from the SQ’s library, with a samāʿ dated 651H in Aleppo in SQ’s hand. Often confused with another treatise on retreat, K. al-Khalwa (RG255) (as OY has done with Yusuf Aga 7838 copy). Other mss listed: Dar al-Kutub: dated 602H in collection 23 maj. (http://www.manuscripts.idsc.gov.eg/Manuscript/Manuscript_OPAC/Availability.aspx?ID=5323&ResID=1) and dated 600H is in collection 31 maj. (http://www.manuscripts.idsc.gov.eg/Manuscript/Manuscript_OPAC/Availability.aspx?ID=5544&ResID=8) - dating almost certainly drawn from dates in text not the date of composition.
R. al-Anwār fi mā yumnaḥ ṣāhib al-khalwa min al-asrār

Often confused with another treatise on retreat, K. al-Khalwa (RG255) (as OY has done with Yusuf Aga 7838 copy).

The function, states and places of the saints who have the spiritual rank of the ‘pole’ (quṭb). This is a series of chapters on the aqṭāb which became part of the FM chapters 462-489, with poems up to 557 (corresponding to sifr 17 of 20 in the first recension).

OY lists only one ms, Koprulu 766, 1-146, which is an early text. It carries no date, but evidence suggests that it may date to late 7th century (the scribe is the same as that of Farghānī’s Muntahā al-madārik listed here http://41.32.191.214/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=39750, dated 704H). We have found a second text in the Ulu Cami library in Bursa, but as we have not yet obtained a digital copy, cannot compare the two mss. JC notes discrepancy between the text and the added red numbers from ch. 4 onwards: from chapter “five” to chapter “sixteen” the red ink number (467-478) is one less than the corresponding FM chapter number (ch.468-479); from chapter “seventeen” to “sixty” the red ink number (479-522) is four less than the corresponding FM chapter number (ch.483-526); from chapter “sixty-one” to “ninety-one” (the last in the ms) there are no red ink numbers – and these correspond to FM ch.527-557. In summary, the text of RG 35 K. al-Aqṭāb has the appearance of a highly abbreviated version of FM ch.462-557, omitting ch.480-482 entirely. It is possible that RG 35 is an early form or summary of sifr 17 of the first recension text of FM.
Related Item: FM ch. 462-479 and ch. 483-557 (or sifr 17 of first recsension of FM) (see biblio comments)

Mss. Koprulu 766, undated but written in the lifetime of IA by Muhammad b. Abdallah al-Tamimi al-Mahdawi Similar to Chapters 462-553 in Futuhat, but clearly an earlier version, with less elaboration and poetry. A close comparison of the handwriting shows that Tamimi is also the scribe for the texts of (stolen) Yusuf Aga 4868, which OY and others have ascribed to IA (eg Hilyat al-abdal) From SH

A collection of fourteen prayers, one for each night and day of the week. For a detailed structure and analysis of the prayers, see Pablo Beneito and Stephen Hirtenstein Seven Days of the Heart (Oxford, 2000), with critical edition as Prayers for the Week (Oxford, 2021).

There are no historic mss. and all the surviving texts are late, though always attributed to IA. The earliest dated copy is Carullah 1094 (939H), but Veliyuddin 1833 may be older. According to Stephen Hirtenstein and Pablo Beneito it is authentic on textual grounds, and the lack of early copies is attributed to the work being only copied for close disciples, not open diffusion. There is another relatively early manuscript of Evradü’l-Eyyami’s-Seb’a (dated 949H or 950H) in Topkapi E.H. 1072 with 42 folios according to the online catalogue at https://topkapisarayi.gov.tr/en/manuscripts

On the meaning of the term azal (eternity) in the predecessors of IA such as al-Hallāj and al-Sulamī. The alternative title (K. al-thamānīn wa thalāthīn = 38) refers to the abjad total of the word azal.

Verified by at least five historic mss. The holograph Yusuf Aga 4868 was written in 615H in Malatya, and Carullah 2111 is copied from an original which was read before IA. According to OY, it was written 601H in Jerusalem on the basis of a note on Veliyuddin 51, but our investigation shows that no place or date is given. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyyudin 51, JMIAS 40, 2006.)

Holograph copy, with samāʿ 617H in Aleppo (Veliyuddin 1759)

According to Michel Chodkiewicz, this is an esoteric commentary upon the Fātiḥa which completes Chapter 383 of FM which, in the series of ‘waystations’ (manāzil), corresponds to the waystation of the Fātiha.

A much copied work, verified by at least five historic mss. The best is Veliyuddin 1759, which is a holograph with two samāʿs in the presence of IA, one dated 617H in Aleppo, the other dated 627H (Damascus). The title on Beyazit 3750 (253b) says that the work is one of the manāzil in FM; we have checked against the holograph and it is identical. Perhaps needs some further checking (see OY’s comment on p.179).

Treatise on the symbolism of the letter bāʾ, the first manifestation of being and the intermediary between the One and the many. Ibn ‘Arabi says in his preface that he wrote it at the request of one of his disciples, who had asked him to write a work on the Divine Realities, based on a spiritual address he had received regarding the bāʾ.

A much copied work, verified by at least four historic mss. The best is the holograph Yusuf Aga 4868 (undated). The second is Veliyuddin 51, dated 762H, copied from an original in the hand of the author, possibly YA 4868? According to OY, the work was written in 602H in Jerusalem on the basis of a note on Veliyuddin 51, but our investigation shows that no place or date is given. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyyudin 51, JMIAS 40, 2006.)

Commentary by IA himself on his cycle of love poetry, Tarjumān al-Ashwāq (RG 767), bringing out the esoteric meaning of the verses. As IA explains in the preface, he wrote it at the request of Badr al-Ḥabashī and Ibn Sawdakīn in Aleppo in 611H because it had incited the disapproval of some of the local ʿulamāʾ.

A much copied work, verified by two historic mss., Evkaf Muzesi 1713 (873H) and Fatih 5322 (934H), which are both copied from originals written by Ayyūb b. Badr, with samāʿ dated 626H and 616H resp. Most mss. also include the full text of the Tarjuman (RG 767), of which there are also some separate copies. Copy in Baghdad, Iraq Museum 11086/2 which a cataloguer believed was copied in the 7th century (al-Furqān online: https://www.al-furqan.com/our_is_item/manid/1250158/groupid/139348) See: مخطوطات الأدب في المتحف العراقي = Makhṭūṭāt al-adab fī al-Matḥaf al-ʿIrāqī = Catalogue of Manuscripts of Literature In the Iraq Museum Library, p.444 (#1155). After transcribing the usual text in which IA gives the reason he wrote the work the catalogue has this: فرغ منه المؤلف سنة 614H بمدرسة الامير مظفر الدين محمود This information does not occur in most mss: completed 614H in the madrasah of Amīr Muẓaffar al-dīn Maḥmūd. (It occurs in the Shuqayrī edition of 1995).

Ibn ʿArabi’s collected poems, containing more than 800 verses, compiled in the last years of his life and finished in 634H. There are are several different versions of the work, including a six volume holograph of which we do not, at the moment, have a complete copy. Research is therefore ongoing to produce a definitive version of the whole text. The best-known version is the printed edition produced by Bulaq, which only reproduces one volume. An analysis of the different versions can be found in Cook/Hirtenstein: The Great Diwān and its offspring; the collection and dispersion of Ibn ʿArabī’s poetry, in JMIAS 52, 2012.

OY lists 28 mss, of which at least four are historic. The best is Khalili 225, which is volume (juzʾ) 4 of the holograph, dated 634H in Damascus. The other holographs, Yusuf Aga 5502 and 5503, were stolen without being previously microfilmed, so there is no access to the texts, although it is believed that Uni 1438 is a copy of the first part.

OY lists 33 mss., of which four can be considered historic, although none is definitive. The note on NO 2406 cannot be regarded as completely reliable, and the text in Shehit Ali 1375 is dated at 722H only on the basis of other works in the collection. But the work appears in other very good collections, such as Carullah 986 and Beyazit 3750, and has been very widely copied. It is also mentioned in the FM, and there is internal evidence of authenticity in the text.

The most famous and widely read of all Ibn ʿArabī’s works, containing the epitome of his teachings on the meaning of the perfect human being (al-insān al-kāmil). It takes the form of 27 chapters on the prophets from Adam to Muhammad, each associated with a knowledge; for example; the wisdom on divinity in the word of Adam: the wisdom of light in the word of Joseph. Ibn ʿArabī’s intention in the Fuṣūṣ is to draw out the interior, saintly wisdom of each prophet rather than the religious law which they brought.

A much copied and commented on work, verified by at least seven historic mss. The best is Evkaf Muzesi 1933, which is SQ’s riwāya. written in his hand in 630H, with two samāʿ in IA’s hand. Other early mss: Kastamonu Hk 2024 (710H), Paris 1340 (726H), Corum Hk 3909 (728H), Konya Ak 308 (757H)

The most famous and widely read of all Ibn ʿArabī’s works, containing the epitome of his teachings on the meaning of the perfect human being (al-insān al-kāmil). It takes the form of 27 chapters on the prophets from Adam to Muhammad, each associated with a knowledge; for example; the wisdom on divinity in the word of Adam: the wisdom of light in the word of Joseph. Ibn ʿArabī’s intention in the Fuṣūṣ is to draw out the interior, saintly wisdom of each prophet rather than the religious law which they brought.

Beirut edition edited by Abu ʿAlā ʿAfīfī (Beirut, nd) is based upon several mss. but did not use the Ṣādr al-dīn al-Qūnawī autograph (Evkaf Musezi 1933). Ibn ʿArabī’s great summary of esoteric knowledge, consisting of 560 chapters and extending to nearly 10,000 pages in the holograph. It totalises all aspects of his work and all the esoteric knowledge of his era. The first recension, completed in Ṣafar 629H, exists only in copies, while the second, written between 632H and 636H, survives in IA’s own hand (see Evkaf Muzesi 1845+). There is still work to be done in distinguishing between the two recensions in the mss base, but considerable progress has been made by Julian Cook and Claude Addas in identifying “markers” which indicate the recension of any given ms. Their research indicates that many later mss. may be hybrids of the two recensions. For details of their work on the two recensions, see ancillary documents.
Verified by many mss. in both recensions. The best of the second recension is Evkaf Muzesi 1845+ in 37 volumes, which is the original in IA’s hand, written in 636H and carrying over 71 samāʿ.

Ibn ʿArabī’s great summary of esoteric knowledge, consisting of 560 chapters and extending to nearly 10,000 pages in the holograph. It totalises all aspects of his work and all the esoteric knowledge of his era. The first recension, completed in Ṣafar 629H, exists only in copies, while the second, written between 632H and 636H, survives in IA’s own hand (see Evkaf Muzesi 1845+).

There is still work to be done in distinguishing between the two recensions in the mss base, but considerable progress has been made by Julian Cook and Claude Addas in identifying “markers” which indicate the recension of any given ms. Their research indicates that many later mss. may be hybrids of the two recensions. For details of their work on the two recensions, see ancillary documents.

Two critical editions exist. The first, edited by Osman Yahia (Cairo, 1970+) consists of 14 volumes and is incomplete.

The second , edited by ʿAbd al-ʿAzīz Sulṭān al-Manṣūb (Yemen, 2011) is in 12 volumes and is complete. It is largely based upon the Konya autograph – the manuscript of the second recension of the book written in 37 sections by Ibn ʿArabī himself – but also takes into account other texts.

Critical edition of the poems on the letters in chapter 2 by Maurizio Marconi in Azufre Rojo vo. 7 (2020).

Eric Winkel is working on one, and information on how to access his translation can be found on http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/infopdf/futuhat-winkel-announcement.pdf. and https://www.createspace.com/pub/simplesitesearch.search.do?sitesearch_query=Eric+A.+Winkel&sitesearch_type=STORE.

Dating: note exact date in composition See Jane and Denis (vel.51): The title is given on 132a and the text itself starts on 132b. At the end, on 136a, there is a note saying that it was copied in 762 in the hand of Ahmad b. M. b. Muthabbit, who took it from the handwriting of the author, who said at the end of the book that he had composed it in Malatya, in Anatolia, on the 9th of Rabî’ al-awwal 602 [AP: Yusuf Agha has 9]. Osman Yahia does not mention this note, although he correctly lists the text as having been copied from an original. The date exactly agrees with that on Yusuf Aga 4868, which is the best copy of the text.[24] But it is not the actual date of composition of the work, which is given in the preface as 599 in Mecca.[25] This opens up the intriguing possibility that Yusuf Aga 4868 was the original from which Ahmad copied this version of Hilyat, although a comparison of the two collections as a whole does not throw up any further obvious correlations. AP: this also raises the possibility that Ibn Muthabbit is given the dates these works were originally copied NOT originally composed... raises an issue.

OY lists four mss: he considers it a resumé of RG 297, ʿIqd al-manẓūm , and the mss. are classified in a very confusing way between the two RGs. A quick check of all the mss. shows that they are fundamentally the same work, with some variations. We therefore suggest reclassifying all of them under RG 384. There are no definitive historic mss., although Shehit Ali 1341 is early. OY has Veliyudin 51 as copied from an original, but in our opinion the note refers to the previous work (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley in JMIAS 36). Nevertheless, the work appears in many early collections and there is a good case for its authenticity.

Related Item: RG 297 (OY duplicate) Denis and Jane (Vel.51): . Osman Yahia calls it K. ‘Iqd al-manzûm and assigns to it RG 297 along with eight other manuscripts. However, he also assigns RG 384, Madkhal fî’ilm al-hurûf to four of these. This has led to a very confusing situation which requires another article to satisfactorily resolve.[27] The question of the status of the work in Veliyuddin 51, however, can be addressed. Although it has no specific notes attached to it, it may well be covered by the general note on 84a, in which case it would have been copied from an original autograph. On the other hand, it is at the end of the collection and the following work, Istilâhât al-sûfiyya, although it has a note with a copying date (see below), again makes no mention of having been taken from an autograph. In view of the consistent notes throughout the rest of the collection, it may be that these last two works were added slightly later from other sources, and so were not covered by the note on 84a. None of the other manuscripts have a provenance which would definitively establish ‘Iqd al-manzûm as an Ibn ‘Arabî work, and Veliyuddin 51 has therefore been cited as the best source. But on the basis of what we have said above, the evidence is not sufficient to prove authenticity beyond doubt.

A bibliography written by IA in which he lists 260 (+) of his works and 70 of his teachers. It was written for a sultan, variously known as al-Muẓaffar or al-Muʿaẓẓam Bahāʾ al-Dīn or Shihāb al-Dīn Ghāzī b. al-Malik al-ʿĀdil, in 632H in Damascus.

OY cites 16 mss, although none can be considered historic. There are several ‘families’: one is represented by Koprulu 766 (dated by TRF as 632H but we have not been able to find evidence for this); another by Princeton Garrett 4098 (dated 949H) and Zahiriyya 4679 (dated 1305); and the third by Badawi’s edition (and other printed editions). Work ascribed to IA on the life and qualities of the Prophet, including the palm-tree miracle in Seville. The text has been analysed by Pablo Beneito (JMIAS 30, 2001).

OY cites no surviving mss., but we have inspected an early mss. in Jerusalem (Khalidiyya 967, 701H, of which there is a microfilm copy in the Dār al-kutub, Cairo.) which carries a dedication to IA’s sons and his daughter Fāṭima. This makes it highly likely that it is an authentic work. The work is mentioned in both the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142) and Ijāza li-l-malik al-Muẓaffar (RG 269) and internal evidence as presented by Pablo Beneito (see JMIAS 30, 2001) supports the verification. There is some confusion between this work and K. al-Shamāʾil al-nabī, for which OY lists three mss and assigned a separate RG number (669). But our research so far indicates that there is only one work with variant titles. We have therefore consolidated under RG 276 and categorised RG 669 as a duplicate.

Small work, in the form of 260 sayings of different contemplatives and spiritual travellers. It is divided into seven chapters; the first six on Vision, Hearing, the Word, Union, Knowledge and Love, with the seventh, longer, chapter dealing with a diversity of subjects. According to OY, based upon the Carullah 986 ms., it was composed in Baghdad, but in our reading of the note (see 47b) it is more likely that it was copied or collated there.

OY cites 27 mss., of which at least two can be considered as historic: Beyazid 3750 (c.782H) which was copied from IA’s original, and Carullah 286 (undated but early) which carries a note (see 47b) saying that it was copied and collated against a copy which had been read to the author; also Khalidiyya 892 (c.656H)

One of Ibn ʿArabī’s most important minor treatises, this work deals with the fundamental premises of his metaphysics; the Divine Essence and Attributes, the human being as the intermediary between Creator and Creation, and the author’s conception of the Universal Reality (al-haqīqa al-kulliya). Built around a pronounced philosophical framework, almost in the kalām style, and copiously illustrated with diagrams and tables. (Fenton and Gloton).

A much copied work, verified by two historic mss.: Manisa 1183 (655H taken from al-Ḥabashī’s copy), and Veliyuddin 1686 (c.667 and copied by disciple of SQ’s). We know from its mention in al-Tadbīrāt al-Ilāhīya (see Elmore JMIAS 29) that this was one of the first works IA began, but the surviving versions are later, probably written in Tunis in 598/1202 at the home of al-Mahdawī (see FM. Chapter 4).

OY cites 10 mss., verified by two historic mss., Veliyuddin 51 (c.762H, taken from original in the hand of IA dated 601H) and Yusuf Ağa 7838. A much copied work, verified by at least seven historic mss. However, there are three verifiable versions of the original text: version A in Damascus (begins with waqt), without introduction, copied by Ayyūb b. Badr (see Manisa 1183, c. 650H), version B in Konya in a different order (begins with hājis), with an introduction, which was written in Malatya in 615H (see Milli 571, 668H), and version C which was included in the FM (II 128–34; Chapter 173, the response to al-Tirmidhī’s question 153), and consists of version B in reverse order with added questions linking each term.

A response to various questions about mystical and esoteric matters posed by al-Tirmidhī (d. 285/898) in his famous work, Khatm al-awliyāʾ (Seal of the Saints). It consists of 55 questions and answers. A similar section is included in FM 2:39-139, but according to Michel Chodkiewicz it is not identical to this work.

OY lists 11 mss., the best being Veliyuddin 1759, which is a holograph, undated but necessarily before 638H. OY dates the composition as 603H based on a note on Beyazit 3750 (253b), but we could not find any indication of this; it looks as if there has been confusion with another work in the same collection.

Add A titre d'informations complémentaires je signale que le fameux questionnaire de Tirmidhî a suscité d'autres réponses: -Qurrat-al-'ayn fî l-jawâb 'an al-as'ila al-muwadda'a fî khabi'at al-kawn; (inédit sauf erreur); ouvrage du shaykh Ahmad al-'Ayyâshî Sukayraj al-Ansârî, shaykh tijânî mort en 1944. -Al-jawâb al-shafî 'alâ as'ilat al-Hakîm al-Tirmidhî, (Le Caire, 1987) dont l'auteur, Muhammad 'Alî Salâma identifie le khatm muhammadî avec le shaykh égyptien Abû l-'Azâ'im, mort en 1938. Je n'ai pu lire le premier de ces deux ouvrages; le second est d'une décevante platitude. Corr Contrairement à ce qu'indiquait O. Y. cet ouvrage n'est pas "inclus dans les Futûhât ", ainsi que l'a d'ailleurs montré O.Y. lui-même par la suite dans son édition du Khatm al-awliyâ' de Tirmidhî, Beyrouth 1965. Il publie en effet en notes (pp. 142 à 326) les réponses au questionnaire de Tirmidhî qui figurent dans le Jawâb mustaqîm et celles, beaucoup plus longues et très différentes dans leur contenu, qui se trouvent dans le chapitre 73 des Futûhât. Les deux textes ont le même objet mais ne peuvent en aucune façon être considérés comme identiques. (MC)

Commentaries on the 99 Divine Names of God. After a brief introduction in which the traditional theological categories of the Names are laid out, the 99 Names of God (as in al-Ghazālī’s listing) are treated according to three concepts (first proposed by Abū Madyan): taʿalluq (dependence); taḥaqquq (realisation); and takhalluq (assimilation). Critical edition and Spanish translation by P. Beneito.

OY lists 22 mss., although none can be considered truly historic. However, the evidence is compelling: Ulu Cami 1581 (c.826H) may have been copied from an original, as it carries a note by IA about the composition of the work, that it was written in Ramaḍān 621H for a known disciple, Sharafuddīn Abū Muḥammad ʿAbd al-Wāḥid b. Abū Bakr b. Sulaymān al-Ḥamawī. The earliest copy is Fatih 5298, dated 783H, which also has a colophon saying that it is a work by IA and that it was dictated to a student in 621H in Damascus. A work of this title is listed in both the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142) and Ijāza l-il-malik al-Muẓaffar (RG 269), and there is a correspondence with other works on the Divine Names (see FM 559).

A work of this title is mentioned by IA in his Fihris, as being amongst those books which he left behind when he left the Maghreb. If the ms. found in Turkey are of the same work, then IA must have rewritten it later, as he did with several other works. In fact , there are no good historical ms of this work, and PB, in producing a critical edition, has relied upon a number of later works, the earliest being 783H (Fatih 5298). A colophon at the end of the work identifies it as definitely being by Ibn ‘Arabi, but reveals that it was dictated extemporaneously to one Sharaf al-d∆n Muπammed “Abd al-Wåπid b. Ab∆ Bakr of Hama during sessions in Imåm al-Ghazzålis zåwiyya during the fast of Ramadan in 621/1224. (source, Elmore’s review in JMIAS 27). The resulting book does not seem to have circulated widely until Ottoman times.

A much copied work (OY lists 35 mss.), verified by three historic mss. The best are Shehit Ali 1341 (724H taken from an original in the hand of IA), Manisa 1183 (650H, written by a direct student of IA’s), and Veliyuddin 51 (762H and copied from IA’s original). According to OY, it was written 601H in Jerusalem on the basis of a note on Veliyuddin 51, but our investigation shows that he has confused the place of copying with the place of writing. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyyudin 51, JMIAS 40, 2006.) Further mss identified by JC: Bankipore ms 955/1 (778H), said to be transcribed from autograph; KÖPRÜLÜ Fazıl Ahmed Pş 53, ff. 109-163

OY states that there are no extant mss of this work, but three copies have now been found: the earliest is Zahiriyya 16632, which is in the hand of al-Farghānī, probably dateable to 660s. There are also much later less reliable copies in the Budeiri library, 142, and in the Dar al-Kutub, Cairo, Taymur 147. An intricate treatise describing an elaborate hierarchy of ‘way-stations’ or ‘abodes’ (see Michel Chodkiewicz, Ocean, 64–67). There are 19 major manāzil, corresponding to 19 classes of Qur’anic suras, many of which are sub-divided. The work is also known as Kitāb al-fahwāniyya, a technical term designating the Divine Speech addressing the servant face to face in the presence of imagination. Here, it denotes the comprehensive way-station of basmala, which has 19 letters. The treatise ends with an account of the mystical ascent (mirʿāj). See FM I:171-180.

OY lists 10 mss., with one very good historic ms. verifying the work: the holograph Veliyuddin 1759 (618H) with a samāʿ written by Ibn Sawakīn in Aleppo. It also appears in other good collections, particularly Beyazid 3750 and Carullah 986. OY dates the composition to 603H based on a note at the end of Beyazit 3750 (432a), but we could not verify this; it is possible that there is some confusion with a note on another work.

Add Edition par Sa'îd 'Abd al-Fattâh, Le Caire, 1995 (précédé de RG. 269 et suivi de RG. 46). Cette édition est exclusivement basée sur le ms. autographe Veliyuddin 1759 dont l'écriture maghrébine est peu familière à l'éditeur.On y repère certaines erreurs de lecture que signale en général une incorrection grammaticale. Elle est néanmoins très utile mais sa courte introduction est décevante. La notion de fahwâniyya-la "Parole face-à-face" dans le 'âlam al-khayâl-qui apparaît souvent dans les écrits d'Ibn Arabî (Futûhât, Tajalliyât, K. al-'abâdila...) est correctement expliquée par la définition qui se trouve dans Fut., II, p. 128 (question 152, définition n°8) et dans les Istilâhât al-sûfiyya (déf. 192). mais il aurait été souhaitable de signaler qu'elle a chez Ibn Arabî, dans l'emploi du 'ilm al-hurûf, une conséquence importante : à la différence du mode de calcul normal elle oblige à prendre en considération les valeurs numériques des lettres effectivement prononcées (et non pas seulemnt de celles qui sont écrites). C'est pourquoi, par exemple, le nom al-rahmân (=330) a une valeur de 530 dans la hadra fahwaniyya (Fut. I, 185), la lettre râ (=200) y étant comptée deux fois. De même le nom Muhammad (MHMD) dont la somme des lettres est de 92 a, dans la hadra fahwâniyya, la valeur 132 qui correspond à MHMMD. L'éditeur ne semble pas d'autre part avoir vu que, dans cet ouvrage, comme dans le chapitre 22 et dans le fasl al-manâzil des Futûhât, le terme manzil renvoie toujours au Coran et désigne, soit une sourate ou un groupe de sourates, soit un verset, un mot ou une lettre du Livre. C'est cette hiérarchie de significations que l'on doit avoir en vue pour comprendre ce texte apparemment cryptique. Ibn Arabî en donne d'ailleurs lui-même la clef lorsqu'il énumère (p. 113) les 19 catégories de sourates. Il est donc facile de saisir que, par exemple, le manzil al-thanâ' regroupe les cinq sourates qui commencent par al-hamdu li-Llâh, le manzil al-rumûz celles qui commencent par les hurûf nûrâniyya, le manzil al-nidâ celles qui commencent par yâ ayyuhâ etc. Quand Ibn Arabî indique qu'entre tel manzil et tel autre il y a x manâzil, ce nombre est celui des sourates intermédiaires. (Sur le problème des manâzil voir M. Chodkiewicz, Un Océan sans rivage, pp. 87-98; trad anglaise, An Ocean without shore, pp. 64-74.

Add Edition par Sa'îd 'Abd al-Fattâh, Le Caire, 1995 (précédé de RG. 269 et suivi de RG. 46). Cette édition est exclusivement basée sur le ms. autographe Veliyuddin 1759 dont l'écriture maghrébine est peu familière à l'éditeur.On y repère certaines erreurs de lecture que signale en général une incorrection grammaticale. Elle est néanmoins très utile mais sa courte introduction est décevante. La notion de fahwâniyya-la "Parole face-à-face" dans le 'âlam al-khayâl-qui apparaît souvent dans les écrits d'Ibn Arabî (Futûhât, Tajalliyât, K. al-'abâdila...) est correctement expliquée par la définition qui se trouve dans Fut., II, p. 128 (question 152, définition n°8) et dans les Istilâhât al-sûfiyya (déf. 192). mais il aurait été souhaitable de signaler qu'elle a chez Ibn Arabî, dans l'emploi du 'ilm al-hurûf, une conséquence importante : à la différence du mode de calcul normal elle oblige à prendre en considération les valeurs numériques des lettres effectivement prononcées (et non pas seulemnt de celles qui sont écrites). C'est pourquoi, par exemple, le nom al-rahmân (=330) a une valeur de 530 dans la hadra fahwaniyya (Fut. I, 185), la lettre râ (=200) y étant comptée deux fois. De même le nom Muhammad (MHMD) dont la somme des lettres est de 92 a, dans la hadra fahwâniyya, la valeur 132 qui correspond à MHMMD. L'éditeur ne semble pas d'autre part avoir vu que, dans cet ouvrage, comme dans le chapitre 22 et dans le fasl al-manâzil des Futûhât, le terme manzil renvoie toujours au Coran et désigne, soit une sourate ou un groupe de sourates, soit un verset, un mot ou une lettre du Livre. C'est cette hiérarchie de significations que l'on doit avoir en vue pour comprendre ce texte apparemment cryptique. Ibn Arabî en donne d'ailleurs lui-même la clef lorsqu'il énumère (p. 113) les 19 catégories de sourates. Il est donc facile de saisir que, par exemple, le manzil al-thanâ' regroupe les cinq sourates qui commencent par al-hamdu li-Llâh, le manzil al-rumûz celles qui commencent par les hurûf nûrâniyya, le manzil al-nidâ celles qui commencent par yâ ayyuhâ etc. Quand Ibn Arabî indique qu'entre tel manzil et tel autre il y a x manâzil, ce nombre est celui des sourates intermédiaires. (Sur le problème des manâzil voir M. Chodkiewicz, Un Océan sans rivage, pp. 87-98; trad anglaise, An Ocean without shore, pp. 64-74.

An early work, written in the Maghreb, but we do not know whether the version we have is the same as the first recension. It consists of 14 contemplations in the style of Niffarī’s Mawāqif. There are two commentaries, one by Ibn Sawdakīn and one by Sitt al-ʿAjam, which have been used in a critical Spanish edition and an English translation of Mashāhid. There are two associated works; a prologue which is classifed by OY as RG 626, and a commentary by Ibn Sawdakīn classified as RG 684.

A much copied work, verified by three historic mss. The best is probably Manisa 1183 (651H, copied by a direct disciple of IA’s) and Veliyuddin 1782 (929H, copied from an original dated 596H). Some texts include the prologue (RG 626) and an epilogue. We have classified all these under RG 432 as it is too complex to make distinctions. Michel Chodkiewicz has examined both the Manisa ms, and the Paris National ms (B. N. 6104). He finds a slight difference between them in Ibn ʿArabi’s commentary.

A much copied work, of which there are no historic mss, although Ahmad III A2415 is dated 712H. Brocklemann, according to OY, thinks it is apocryphal and should be attributed to Dhahabī (d.748) (see OY p. 397). But there is textual evidence that it is by IA: Claude Addas, in her biography of IA Quest for the Red Sulphur (Cambridge, 1993), refers to several passages where incidents are described which correspond to information in other verified texts; eg. pp. 211, 223, 227. Also, a work of this title is mentioned in both the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142) and Ijāza li-l-malik al-Muẓaffar (RG 269). Michel Chodkiewicz relates that some years ago he saw an autograph copy, written in Malatya, which is in private ownership in Tunisia, but we have not yet been able to obtain a copy of this. Other mss identified: Ragib Pasha 1204 (944H); Veliyuddin 2573 ff. 1-275 (945H); Düğümlü Baba 392 (950H)

Autobiographical sketches of IA’s masters in al-Andalus, a companion volume to his Rūḥ al-quds (RG 639). This work was written in Andalusia, and therefore there are no extant manuscripts of the original work. However, Ibn ʿArabī rewrote a version of the text later for a friend in Damascus, and this is the text, entitled K. Mukhtaṣar al-Durra al-fākhira, that we now have. Abrar Ahmad adds: Shaykh Ibn Arabi says in the first paragraph of this Mukhtaṣar al-Durra al-Fākhira: سألني بعض من يكرم علي من إخواني بمحروسة دمشق أن أوقفه على كتاب أودعته ذكر بعض من لقيته فانتفعت به في طريق الأخرة فلم يكن عندي حاضرا عند سواله فإني تركته بالمغرب فقيدت له هذا المختصر في ذكر بعض المشيخة؟ من أهل الله المتمكنين في طريق أهل التحقيق من الصالحين العارفين رضي الله عنهم جميعهم مستعينًا بالله تعالى ولم أذكر فيه إلا من لقيته ورأيته وصحبته من رجال ونساء وكبير في السن وصغير على قدر ما تذكرت منهم في هذا الوقت. وذكرت على كل واحد منهم حكاية رأيتها منه من كلام حكمة أو خرق عادة أو موعظة و تركت منهم كثيرا أضعاف ما ذكرت. (مختصر الدرة الفاخرة - الصفحة الأولي للمخطوط)

There are only two extant mss.: one, Esad Ef. 1777, is listed by OY as Al-durrat al-fākhira (RG 105) and is late (1006H); the other OY lists as RG 496, K. Mukhtaṣar al-durrat al-fākhira in Veliyuddin 1800. OY lists Esad Efendi under both classifications, and Veliyuddin 1800/186-201B, under RG 496 only. We would suggest that they should both be under RG 496. The Veliyuddin ms. is early (715H) and presumably the source for Esad Ef. The main factor in considering this a verified work is the correlation with the well-verified work Rūḥ al-quds (RG 639) and the fact that it relates many of the same incidents.

OY lists 16 mss., of which three can be considered historic. The best is Yusuf Ağa 7838 (undated, but most probably written in IA’s lifetime). According to OY, the work was written in 601H in Jerusalem on the basis of notes on Veliyuddin 51 and Bayazid 3750. But our investigation of Vel. 51 shows that he has confused the place of copying with the place of writing and in fact, the note says it was written in Damascus in 602H. Bayazid 3750 likewise does not mention Jerusalem, but confirms the date of Jumādā l-ūlā 602H. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyyudin 51, JMIAS 40, 2006.)

Jane and Denis (Vel.51): It was written (kutiba) in the city of Damascus in the month of Jumâdâ l-ûlâ of the year 602.

According to OY, the work was written in 601H in Jerusalem on the basis of notes on Veliyuddin 51 and Bayazid 3750. But our investigation of Vel. 51 shows that he has confused the place of copying with the place of writing and in fact, the note says it was written in Damascus in 602H. Bayazid 3750 likewise does not mention Jerusalem, but confirms the date of Jumādā l-ūlā 602H. (See Jane Clark and Denis McAuley Some Notes on the Manuscript Veliyyudin 51, JMIAS 40, 2006.)

A collection of 21 poems written in the muwashshaḥ style – a specifically Andalusian form of poetry which was common to the Muslims, Jews and Christians of the region.

There is only one copy of this text, Shehit Ali 1389 (c.777H), which has a note saying it was taken from a copy in the hand of IA. There was also a copy now lost in Yusuf Ağa 5503. A comparison with the muwashshaḥāt in the Bulaq Dīwān reveals that the 21 poems in the ms. are all in the Great Dīwān, although the order in which they are presented is different and there are minor textual variations. It is therefore unclear whether this is an extract from some version of the Dīwān, or an earlier version of a work which was later incorporated into it, so for the time being it is regarded as a stand-alone work.

رسالة الشيخ العربي إلي أبي علي الغزال

A short letter to al-Ghazzāl, a disciple of the Andalusian mystic Ibn al-ʿArīf (d. 536/1141 in Marrakesh). The work is also known as R. al-Nashʾatayn (RG 533, as given in both the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142) and Ijāza li-l-malik al-Muẓaffar (RG 269)). This correspondence was exchanged before the final departure of IA for the East in 598H (see the preface to the text and Rūḥ al-Quds (RG 639) (OY))

OY lists four mss., of which only one can be considered historic: Veliyuddin 1686 (c.667H, copied by a disciple of SQ’s in Konya). The basis for its status as verified text is the fact that the three poems it contains are all in the Paris Dīwān (BN 2348). This work has a variant title of R. al-Nashʾatayn for which OY has created a separate RG (533), which is listed in both the lists which IA made of his own works, Fihris muʾallafāt al-shaykh al-akbar (RG142) and Ijāza li al-malik al-Muẓaffar (RG 269). However, we have consolidated the mss. under RG 611, as it is the title which appears most frequently on the mss. themselves.

Commentary on the work of the Andalusian mystic, Abū al-Qāsim b. Qasiy, (d. 546/1151, Marrakesh). He claimed to be the Mahdī, and organised an anti-Almoravid rebellion in the Algarve. IA claims to have met his son in 590H. IA was very critical of his ideas in this work. See Addas Quest for the Red Sulphur, (Cambridge, 1993. pp. 55-7) for more on both the original and the commentary.

OY lists five mss., of which we have investigated four. The work is verified by three historic works: Shehit Ali 1174 (741H, copied from an original riwāya Ibn Sawdakīn), Veliyuddin 1673 (677H) and Yusuf Ağa 7838 (640H from SQ’s library). There is also a work of the same title attributed to ʿAbd Allah Bosnevi (d. 1054/1644) which has caused some confusion.

Maxims, consisting of a number of short conundrums, counsels, instruction, intimations, quotations and allusions. Gerald Elmore (see ‘A Selection of texts on the theme of praise from some gnomic works by Ibn ʿArabī’ in JMIAS 23, pp. 58-85) feels that this text is closely related to K, al-Tarājim (RG 737), which is probably the ‘mother’ text, but further research is needed to ascertain which came first.

This is one of IA’s earliest works, written in four days during a visit to his friend al-Mawrūrī in the village of Moron in Andalusia. It was inspired by Sirr al-Asrār (The Secrets of Secrets) by pseudo-Aristotle concerning the nature of government, with IA adding a spiritual dimension to the discussion. In 21 chapters, it explains the correspondences between the external political hierarchy of princes and rulers, and the inner rulership of the spirit within the human being.

A much copied work, verified by at least three historic mss. The best is probably Leiden Or 86, written possibly in 606H. Also Corum 756 (part 1) and Yusuf Ağa 4859 (part 2) from SQ’s library, which were originally the same document, undated. Yusuf Aga 4859 was stolen but a copy exists on digitised microfilm. Koprulu 713 seems to be a complete copy of this original dated 663H. OY also lists four commentaries, including one by al-Dāmūnī (d. 1199/1785).

OY lists four mss., of which none are historic. All texts are relatively late and without special provenance, so it must be considered unverified. Ryad Atlagh is convinced that it is authentic and has presented his arguments in a paper The Phenomenology of the Perfect Man in The Tāʾiyya of Ibn ʿArabī (unpublished, MIAS Symposium, Oxford 1998). All copies we have seen are attributed to IA (varying in length but at least 400 verses). A line-by-line commentary by Abdullah Bosnevi entitled Qurrat ʿayn al-shuhūd also testifies to its authorship by IA. In light of the importance given by Bosnevi to this poem, it is most likely that the original Tāʾiyya should be considered as an authentic work. Critical edition by Yusuf ‘Awda (Cairo, 2015)

Cor Il ne s'agit pas d'un recueil de sept épîtres comme l'indique O. Y., mais de huit épîtres. O.Y. mentionne en fait comme une seule épître (Lettre divine sacro-sainte) deux épîtres distinctes (Risâla ilâhiyya/Risâla qudsiyya). La troisième lettre de sa liste-la quatrième en fait-est intitulée par lui "lettre seigneuriale". Or le titre arabe, tel qu'il figure dans le ms. autographe, n'est pas risâla rabbâniyya comme cette traduction le donnerait à penser mais Risâla suryâniyya (autre lecture possible : Risâla sarayâniyya, hypothèse qui serait à mettre en relation avec la formulation sarayân al-ma'bûd fî l-wujûd qui apparaît à la fin de l'ouvrage, f. 144a du ms autographe). O.Y. a sans doute retenu le nombre sept parce qu'il correspond manifestement à celui des tournées rituelles autour de la Ka'ba. Ce symbolisme semble remis en question par l'existence de huit épîtres ; or une phrase de la quatrième lettre montre qu'il n'en est rien : elle rappelle en effet qu'au terme des sept tournées le rite du tawâf doit se clore par un huitième acte-l'accomplissement d'une prière de 2 rak'at devant le maqâm ibrâhîm. S'il est donc en parfaite cohérence avec les gestes successifs prescrits au pèlerin lorsqu'il arrive devant la Ka'ba, le nombre huit trouve son explication la plus profonde dans la nature des termes, chaque fois différent, par lesquels Ibn Arabî se désigne lui-même au début de chaque épître : il se présente d'abord comme 'Abd Allâh puis comme 'Abd al-Hayy, 'Abd al-'Alîm, 'Abd al-Shakûr, 'Abd al-Basîr, 'Abd al-Samî', 'Abd al-Wadûd et enfin 'Abd al-Qâdir. Ces huit dénominations correspondent de toute évidence au Nom de l'Essence (Allâh) puis aux sept attributs qui se manifestent à lui dans sa contemplation du Bayt Allâh et définissent chacun un aspect particulier de sa 'ubûdiyya.

Descriptions of 109 theophanies or ‘unveilings’, including IA’s encounters and conversations in the intermediary world (barzakh) with his predecessors, such as Sahl al-Tustārī, Dhū al-Nūn, Junayd etc., which illustrate themes such as unification, perfection, generosity and compassion.

A much copied work, verified by at least five historical mss. The best is Veliyuddin 1759 (620H, holograph, with a samāʿ in Damascus in the house of IA). The earliest copy is held in Awqāf Baghdad 36175 (OY: 4827), dated 606H, and transcribed into a modern edition by ʿAlī Daḥrūj

Work composed in Mosul in 601H, on the esoteric significance of ablution and prayers, describing how each phase of everyday ritual is imbued with meaning. Consists of 55 chapters.

OY lists 31 mss., and it is verified by at least nine historic mss. The best is a holograph, Murad Bukhari 162 (with a samāʿ dated 620H and a note verifying that it was written by IA), Murad Molla 1257 (621H, written by Ayyūb b. Badr) and Yusuf Ağa 4861 (written by SQ).
Tanazzul al-imlâk li-l-amlâk fi harakât al-aflâk: K. tanazzul al-imlâk min ‘âlam al-arwâh wa-l aflâk.
K. al-Tanazzulât al-mawsiliyya fi asrâr al-tahârât wa al-salawât wa-l-ayyâm al-asliyya:

RG 762 Tanazzulât mawsiliyya Add Une première édition a été publiée au Caire en 1961 par Ahmad Zakî 'Atiya et 'Abd al-Bâqî Surûr sous le titre Latâ'if al-asrâr. Une deuxième édition a été publiée au Caire également, en 1986, par le shaykh 'Abd al-Rahmân Hasan Mahmûd sous le titre Tanazzulât mawsiliyya . Ni l'une ni l'autre (basées sur des mss. égyptiens) ne répond aux critères d'une édition scientifique. Une édition critique, établie en vue du Ph.D. à Cambridge en 1996, doit paraître prochainement à Beyrouth. Elle est due à Karîm Lahhâm, qui a recensé 35 mss. (O.Y. en recensait 30 mais, par suite de doubles emplois, sa liste se ramenait en fait à 27 mss.)L'édition à venir de Karîm Lahhâm est basée principalement sur le ms. autographe (Murâd Bukhari 162) et celui transcrit par Qûnâwî (Yusûf Aga 4861) mais note aussi les variantes relevées dans huit autres mss. Elle comporte 55 chapitres (et non 53 comme indiquée par O.Y.). L'introduction met en évidence la complémentarité entre le thème de la descente, développée dans les 45 premiers chapitres, et celui de l'ascension (mi'râj) qui caractérise les 10 derniers chapitres.

RG 762 Tanazzulât mawsiliyya Add Une première édition a été publiée au Caire en 1961 par Ahmad Zakî 'Atiya et 'Abd al-Bâqî Surûr sous le titre Latâ'if al-asrâr. Une deuxième édition a été publiée au Caire également, en 1986, par le shaykh 'Abd al-Rahmân Hasan Mahmûd sous le titre Tanazzulât mawsiliyya . Ni l'une ni l'autre (basées sur des mss. égyptiens) ne répond aux critères d'une édition scientifique. Une édition critique, établie en vue du Ph.D. à Cambridge en 1996, doit paraître prochainement à Beyrouth. Elle est due à Karîm Lahhâm, qui a recensé 35 mss. (O.Y. en recensait 30 mais, par suite de doubles emplois, sa liste se ramenait en fait à 27 mss.)L'édition à venir de Karîm Lahhâm est basée principalement sur le ms. autographe (Murâd Bukhari 162) et celui transcrit par Qûnâwî (Yusûf Aga 4861) mais note aussi les variantes relevées dans huit autres mss. Elle comporte 55 chapitres (et non 53 comme indiquée par O.Y.). L'introduction met en évidence la complémentarité entre le thème de la descente, développée dans les 45 premiers chapitres, et celui de l'ascension (mi'râj) qui caractérise les 10 derniers chapitres.

61 mystical love poems to the Divine Beauty, in the qaṣīda form of pre-Islamic poetry. According to Pablo Beneito (Qurrat al-ʿAyn, 2020), the original collection was 60 odes, to which were added first one then two poems in the preface. It was composed in 611H in Mecca, although the inspiration came in 604H in the meeting with Qurrat al-ʿAyn.

A much copied work, both on its own and with the commentary (RG116). There are no definitive historic mss. to verify the text in its own right, but there are several for the commentary, which includes the text of the poems. The best copies are therefore contained within mss. of Dhakhāʾir . The best stand-alone mss. are Manisa 6596 (undated, taken from SQ’s copy), and Ragib Pasha 1453 (although very late, probably also taken from SQ’s copy). There is an issue with the preface on this work. There are two basic variants; some mss carry the same preface as the commentary, Dhakhāʾir al-alāq (RG 116. Others have a longer version which begin with a khutba and IA’s account of meeting the young girl, Niẓam, who inspired the poems in Mecca. The situation is complex, with several other variants appearing in some mss (see Jane Clark Mystical Perception and Beauty: Ibn ʿArabī’s Preface to Tarjumān al-Ashwāq in JMIAS 55, 2013).

OY lists 6 mss., none of which can be considered historic. Carullah 2080 (c791H in Konya) is listed by OY as being copied from an original but we could find no specific note to this effect on the text. There are a number of works with similar titles, and there is much work to be done in distinguishing them from one another. However, there is a definite unique work listed here under RG 821, with at least four mss. (Carullah 2070, Husein Celebi 448, Milli 489 and Shehit Ali 1344) being versions of the same text. N.B. OY also lists Shehit Ali 1344 under RG 817.

OY lists only one ms., Ayasofia 376 (997H), on which the Hyderabad 1948 Rasāʾil Ibn ʿArabi is based. Julian Cook argues that this is a distinct work from RG 821 (of which RG 817 is a duplicate). He has identified that within the text there are three poems (pp. 2, 5 and 7), each of which is also found in ch. 560 of Futuhat – also known as RG 818 Waṣāyā (or even Waṣiyya). So it could well be this work is in fact a set of extracts from there. Further investigation required.
